event.title: reached the site of Duncan in 1866

data.event: The transcontinental railroad reached the site of Duncan in 1866.

event.title: June 1869, the post office of Cherry Hill was established

data.event: In June 1869, the post office of Cherry Hill was established on the site.

event.title: October 1871, the townsite of Jackson was laid out

data.event: In October 1871, the townsite of Jackson was laid out by officials of the Union Pacific Railroad.

Jackson was chosen in 1879 as the southern terminus of the Omaha, Niobrara, and Black Hills Railroad, a Union Pacific subsidiary, purportedly because Jay Gould was angry at Columbus for promoting a rival railroad in the region.
In 1880, the settlement's name was changed to Duncan, owing to the existence of another Jackson in Dakota County.

event.title: the following year, an ice jam destroyed

data.event: In the following year, an ice jam destroyed the Omaha, Niobrara, and Black Hills Railroad bridge across the Loup River; the line was later moved to branch off the main line of the Union Pacific at Columbus.
